intro: Selinopsis foetida, commonly known as the stinking nightshade, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the Solanaceae family, which includes other nightshades like tomatoes and peppers. The plant is characterized by its dark green, hairy leaves and small, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to purple. It produces berries that are toxic to humans and animals, containing alkaloids that can be harmful if ingested. Selinopsis foetida is often found in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to thrive in arid conditions.
